{{see also|Molar mass}} '''Relative molecular mass''' or '''molecular weight''' is the mass of a [[molecule]]. It is calculated as the sum of the [[atomic weight|relative atomic masse]]s of each constituent [[chemical element|element]] multiplied by the number of [[atom]]s of that element in the [[molecular formula]]. The molecular mass of small to medium size molecules, measured by mass spectrometry, determines [[stoichiometry]]. For large molecules such as [[protein]]s, methods based on [[viscosity]] and light-scattering can be used to determine molecular mass when [[crystallographic]] data are not available.
== Definitions == Both atomic and molecular masses are usually obtained relative to the mass of the [[isotope]] <sup>12</sup>C (carbon 12), which by definition<ref name="IUPAC1979">{{cite journal | author = [[International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry]] | title = Atomic Weights of the Elements 1979 | url = http://www.iupac.org/publications/pac/1980/pdf/5210x2349.pdf | doi = 10.1351/pac198052102349 | journal = [[Pure and Applied Chemistry|Pure Appl. Chem.]] | year = 1980 | volume = 52 | pages = 2349–84 | issue = 10}}</ref> is equal to 12. For example, the molecular mass of [[methane]], whose molecular formula is CH<sub>4</sub>, is calculated as follows: :{| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" ! !! Atomic mass !! Number !! Total mass |- | C || {{Atomic mass|C}} || 1 || {{Atomic mass|C}} |- | H || {{Atomic mass|H}} || 4 || {{Molecular mass|H|4}} |- | CH<sub>4</sub> || || || {{Molecular mass|C|1|H|4}} |} A more proper term would be "relative molecular mass". However the adjective 'relative' is omitted as it is universally assumed that atomic and molecular masses are relative to the mass of <sup>12</sup>C. Relative atomic and molecular mass values are [[dimensionless]] but are given the "unit" [[Dalton (unit)|Dalton]] (formerly [[atomic mass unit]]) to indicate that the number is equal to the mass of one molecule divided by {{frac|1|12}} of the mass of one atom of <sup>12</sup>C. The mass of 1 [[mole (chemistry)|mol]] of substance is designated as [[molar mass]]. By definition, it has the unit [[gram (unit)|gram]].
In the example above the atomic mass of carbon is given as 12.011, not 12. This is because naturally occurring carbon is a mixture of the [[isotope]]s <sup>12</sup>C, <sup>13</sup>C and <sup>14</sup>C which have relative atomic masses of 12, 13 and 14 respectively. Moreover, the proportion of the isotopes varies between samples, so 12.011 is an average value. By contrast, there is less variation in naturally occurring hydrogen so the average atomic mass is known more precisely. The precision of the molecular mass is [[Propagation of uncertainty|determined]] by precision of the least precise atomic mass value, in this case that of carbon. In high-resolution [[mass spectrometry]] the isotopomers <sup>12</sup>C<sup>1</sup>H<sub>4</sub> and <sup>13</sup>C<sup>1</sup>H<sub>4</sub> are observed as distinct molecules, with molecular masses of 16 and 17, respectively. The intensity of the mass-spectrometry peaks is proportional to the isotopic abundances in the molecular species. <sup>12</sup>C <sup>2</sup>H <sup>1</sup>H<sub>3</sub> can also be observed with molecular mass of 17.
== Determination == === Mass spectrometry === {{main|Mass spectrometry}} In mass spectrometry, the molecular mass of a small molecule is usually reported as the [[monoisotopic mass]], that is, the mass of the molecule containing only the most common isotope of each element. Note that this also differs subtly from the molecular mass in that the choice of isotopes is defined and thus is a single specific molecular mass of the many possible. The masses used to compute the monoisotopic molecular mass are found on a table of isotopic masses and are not found on a typical periodic table. The average molecular mass is often used for larger molecules since molecules with many atoms are unlikely to be composed exclusively of the most abundant isotope of each element. A theoretical average molecular mass can be calculated using the [[standard atomic weight]]s found on a typical periodic table, since there is likely to be a statistical distribution of atoms representing the isotopes throughout the molecule. This however may differ from the true average molecular mass of the sample due to natural (or artificial) variations in the isotopic distributions.
=== Hydrodynamic methods === To a first approximation, the basis for determination of molecular mass according to [[Mark–Houwink equation|Mark–Houwink relations]]<ref>Paul, Hiemenz C., and Lodge P. Timothy. Polymer Chemistry. Second ed. Boca Raton: CRC P, 2007. 336, 338–339.</ref> is the fact that the [[intrinsic viscosity]] of [[solutions]] (or [[suspension (chemistry)|suspensions]]) of macromolecules depends on volumetric proportion of the dispersed particles in a particular solvent. Specifically, the hydrodynamic size as related to molecular mass depends on a conversion factor, describing the shape of a particular molecule. This allows the apparent molecular mass to be described from a range of techniques sensitive to hydrodynamic effects, including [[dynamic light scattering|DLS]], [[size exclusion chromatography|SEC]] (also known as [[Gel permeation chromatography|GPC]] when the eluent is an organic solvent), [[viscometry]], and diffusion ordered [[nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy]] (DOSY).<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Johnson Jr., C. S. |journal=[[Progress in Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy]]|year=1999| volume=34|pages=203–256|title=Diffusion ordered nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy: principles and applications |doi=10.1016/S0079-6565(99)00003-5}}</ref> The apparent [[Hydrodynamic radius|hydrodynamic size]] can then be used to approximate molecular mass using a series of macromolecule-specific standards.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Neufeld, R. |author2=Stalke, D. |journal=[[Chem. Sci.]]|year=2015| volume=6|pages=3354–3364|title=Accurate Molecular Weight Determination of Small Molecules via DOSY-NMR by Using External Calibration Curves with Normalized Diffusion Coefficients |doi=10.1039/C5SC00670H|url=http://goedoc.uni-goettingen.de/goescholar/bitstream/handle/1/11975/c5sc00670h.pdf?sequence=1}} {{open access}}</ref> As this requires calibration, it's frequently described as a "relative" molecular mass determination method.
=== Static light scattering === It is also possible to determine absolute molecular mass directly from light scattering, traditionally using the [[Zimm plot|Zimm method]]. This can be accomplished either via classical [[static light scattering]] or via [[multi-angle light scattering]] detectors. Molecular masses determined by this method do not require calibration, hence the term "absolute". The only external measurement required is [[Static light scattering#Theory|refractive index increment]], which describes the change in refractive index with concentration.

'''Compounds of nickel''' are chemical compounds containing the element [[nickel]] which is a member of the [[group 10 element|group 10]] of the [[periodic table]]. Most compounds in the group have an [[oxidation state]] of +2. Nickel is classified as a [[transition metal]] with nickel(II) having much chemical behaviour in common with iron(II) and cobalt(II). Many salts of nickel(II) are [[isomorphous]] with salts of [[magnesium]] due to the [[ionic radii]] of the cations being almost the same. Nickel forms many [[coordination complex]]es. [[Nickel tetracarbonyl]] was the first pure metal carbonyl produced, and is unusual in its volatility. [[Metalloprotein]]s containing nickel are found in biological systems.
Nickel forms simple binary compounds with non metals including [[halogens]], [[chalcogenides]], and [[pnictides]]. Nickel ions can act as a cation in salts with many acids, including common [[oxoacid]]s Salts of the hexaaqua ion (Ni•6H<sub>2</sub>O<sup>2+</sup>) are especially well known. Many double salts containing nickel with another cation are known. There are organic acid salts. Nickel can be part of a negatively charged ion (anion) making what is called a nickellate. Numerous quaternary compounds (with four elements) of nickel have been studied for super conductivity properties, as nickel is adjacent to copper and iron in the periodic table can can form compounds with the same structure as the [[high-temperature superconductor]]s that are known.
==General==
{{Empty section|date=February 2017}}
==Colour== Most of the common [[Salt (chemistry)|salts]] of nickel are green due to the presence of hexaaquanickel(II) ion, Ni(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub><sup>2+</sup>.
==Geometry== Nickel atoms can connect to surrounding atoms or ligands in a variety of ways. Six coordinated nickel is the most common and is [[octahedral]], but this can be distorted if ligands are not equivalent. For four coordinate nickel arrangements can be square planar, or [[tetrahedral]]. Five coordinated nickel is rarer.
==Magnetism== Some nickel compounds are [[ferromagnetic]] at sufficiently low temperatures. In order to show magnetic properties the nickel atoms have to be close enough together in the solid structure.
==Binary compounds== A binary compound of nickel contains one other element. Substances that contain only nickel atoms are not actually compounds.
In a [[noble gas matrix]], nickel can form [[Dimer (chemistry)|dimers]], a molecule with two nickel atoms: Ni<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=barrett/> Ni<sub>2</sub> has a bonding energy of 2.07±0.01 eV. For Ni<sub>2</sub><sup>+</sup> the bond energy is around 3.3 eV. Nickel dimers and other clusters can also be formed in a gas and plasma phase by shooting a powerful laser at a nickel rod in cold helium gas.<ref name=lian91>{{cite journal |last1=Lian |first1=Li |last2=Su |first2=C.-X. |last3=Armentrout |first3=P.B. |title=The bond energy of Ni+2 |journal=Chemical Physics Letters |date=May 1991 |volume=180 |issue=3 |pages=168–172 |doi=10.1016/0009-2614(91)87135-X|bibcode=1991CPL...180..168L }}</ref>
===Oxides=== Nickel oxides include [[Nickel(II) oxide]] and [[Nickel(III) oxide]].
===Hydroxides=== Nickel hydroxides are used in [[nickel–cadmium battery|nickel–cadmium]] and [[Nickel–metal hydride battery|Nickel–metal hydride]] batteries. Nickel(II) hydroxide Ni(OH)<sub>2</sub>, the main hydroxide of nickel is coloured apple green. It is known as the mineral [[theophrastite]]. [[Nickel oxide hydroxide|β-NiO(OH)]] is a black powder with nickel in the +3 oxidation state. It can be made by oxidising [[nickel nitrate]] in a cold alkaline solution with [[bromine]]. A [[Mixed valency|mixed oxidation state]] hydroxide Ni<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>(OH)<sub>4</sub> is made if oxidation happens in a hot alkaline solution. A Ni<sup>4+</sup> hydroxide: nickel peroxide hydrate NiO<sub>2</sub>•H<sub>2</sub>O, can be made by oxidising with alkaline peroxide. It is black, and unstable and oxidises water.
===Halides=== [[File:Nickel(II)-chloride-hexahydrate-sample.jpg|thumb|right|nickel chloride hexahydrate]] [[Nickel(II) fluoride]] NiF<sub>2</sub> is yellow, crystallising in the [[rutile structure]] and can form a [[Water of crystallization|trihydrate]], NiF<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=mellor>{{cite book |last1=Mellor |first1=J. W. |chapter=Nickel |title=A COMPREHENSIVE TREATISE ON INORGANIC AND THEORETICAL CHEMISTRY VOLUME XV Ni Ru, Rh Pd, Os, Ir |url=http://tera-3.ul.cs.cmu.edu/NASD/01cf394d-c0ee-4090-918f-a8413fe96bee/China/disk6/73/51-150/31005548/HTML/00000414.htm |accessdate=31 May 2016 |date=May 1936 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170207113127/http://tera-3.ul.cs.cmu.edu/NASD/01cf394d-c0ee-4090-918f-a8413fe96bee/China/disk6/73/51-150/31005548/HTML/00000414.htm |archivedate=7 February 2017 |df= }} (pages accessible by changing number on url)</ref> A tetrahydrate also exists.<ref name="CRC"/>
[[Nickel chloride]] NiCl<sub>2</sub> is yellow, crystallising in the [[cadmium chloride]] structure. It can form a hexahydrate, NiCl<sub>2</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O, a tetrahydrate NiCl<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O over 29 °C and a dihydrate, NiCl<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O over 64 °C.<ref name=mellor/>
[[nickel bromide]] NiBr<sub>2</sub> is yellow, also crystallising in the cadmium chloride structure. It can form a hexahydrate, NiBr<sub>2</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=mellor/> Crystallisation above 29° forms a trihydrate NiBr<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O, and a dihydrate NiBr<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=nicholls>Nicholls p1126-1127</ref> Enneahydrate, NiBr<sub>2</sub>·9H<sub>2</sub>O can crstallise from water below 2 °C.<ref name=mellor/> Nickelous hexammine bromide Ni(NH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>6</sub>Br<sub>2</sub>is violet or blue. It is soluble in boiling aqueous [[ammonia]], but is insoluble in cold.<ref name=mellor/> Diammine, monoammine, and dihydrazine nickel bromides also exist.<ref name=mellor/>
With four bromide atoms nickel(II) forms a series of salts called [[tetrabromonickelates]].
[[Nickel iodide]] NiI<sub>2</sub> is black, also crystallising in the cadmium chloride structure. It can form a green hexahydrate, NiI<sub>2</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=mellor/> Nickel iodide has a brown diammine NiI<sub>2</sub>•2NH<sub>3</sub> and a bluish-violet hexammine NiI<sub>2</sub>•6NH<sub>3</sub>.<ref name=mellor/>
[[Nickel(III) fluoride]] NiF<sub>3</sub>
[[Nickel(IV) fluoride]] NiF<sub>4</sub>
===Chalcogenides=== [[File:Millerite-Quartz-232902.jpg|thumb|right|needles of Halls Gap Millerite]] By reacting nickel with [[chalcogen]]s, [[nickel sulfide]], [[nickel selenide]], and [[nickel telluride]] are formed. There are numerous sulfides: Ni<sub>1.5</sub>S, Ni<sub>17</sub>S<sub>18</sub>, Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>2</sub> ([[heazlewoodite]]), Ni<sub>3</sub>S<sub>4</sub> ([[polydymite]]), Ni<sub>9</sub>S<sub>8</sub> ([[godlevskite]]), NiS ([[millerite]]) and two other NiS forms, NiS<sub>2</sub> ([[vaesite]]) in pyrite structure. Black nickel tetrasulfide NiS<sub>4</sub> is formed from [[ammonium polysulfide]] and nickel in water solution. Mixed and double sulfides of nickel also exist. Nickel with [[selenium]] forms several compounds Ni<sub>1−x</sub>Se 0≤x≤0.15, Ni<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub>, NiSe<sub>2</sub> also known as a mineral [[penroseite]].
Nickel forms two different [[polonide]]s by heating nickel and [[polonium]] together: NiPo and NiPo<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Meyer |first1=R. J. |title=Gmelins Handbuch Der Anorganischen Chemie - Nickel: Teil B — Lieferung 2. Verbindungen bis Nickel-Polonium |date=1974 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=Berlin |isbn=9783662133026 |page=764 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0lGyBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA764 |language=de |chapter=Nickel und Polonium}}</ref>
===Pnictides=== [[File:Nickeline.jpg|thumb | right|The nickel arsenide [[nickeline]]]] [[Non-stoichiometric]] compounds of nickel with [[phosphorus]], [[arsenic]] and [[antimony]] exist, and some are found in nature. One interstitial [[nitride]] has formula Ni<sub>3</sub>N (hexagonal P6322, Z = 2, a = 4.6224 Å and c = 4.3059 Å).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Leineweber |first1=Andreas |last2=Jacobs |first2=Herbert |last3=Hull |first3=Steve |title=Ordering of Nitrogen in Nickel Nitride Ni3N Determined by Neutron Diffraction |journal=Inorganic Chemistry |date=November 2001 |volume=40 |issue=23 |pages=5818–5822 |doi=10.1021/ic0104860}}</ref> In a [[solid nitrogen]] matrix, nickel atoms combine with [[nitrogen molecule]]s to yield Ni(N<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>.<ref name=barrett>{{cite journal |last1=Barrett |first1=Paul H. |last2=Montano |first2=P. A. |title=Proposed iron–nitrogen molecule produced in a solid nitrogen matrix |journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Faraday Transactions 2 |date=1977 |volume=73 |issue=3 |pages=378–383 |doi=10.1039/F29777300378}}</ref>
[[Nickel phosphide]] Ni<sub>2</sub>P has density 7.33 and melts at 1100 °C.<ref name="CRC"/>
The mineral [[Nickelskutterudite]] has formula NiAs<sub>2-3</sub>, [[nickeline]] has formula NiAs and [[breithauptite]] has formula NiSb. NiAs melts at 967° and has density 7.77. NiSb melts at 1174°. It has the highest density of a nickel compound at 8.74 g/cm<sup>3</sup>.<ref name="CRC"/>
NiAsS [[gersdorffite]], and NiSbS [[ullmannite]], NiAsSe [[Jolliffeite]] are pnictide/chalcogenide compounds that occur as minerals.
===Other=== Nickel also forms [[carbide]]s and [[boride]]s. [[Nickel boride]] can take the forms Ni<sub>2</sub>B (a green/black solid), NiB, Ni<sub>3</sub>B, ''o''-Ni<sub>4</sub>B<sub>3</sub> and ''m''-Ni<sub>4</sub>B<sub>3</sub>.<ref name="Encyclopedia">{{cite book | title=Encyclopedia of Inorganic Chemistry | chapter=Boron: Inorganic Chemistry | author1=Robert A. Scott | publisher=Wiley | year=2011 | isbn=9780470862100 | page=401 }}</ref> [[Nickel hydride]] NiH is only stable under [[high pressure]]s of [[hydrogen]].
===Diatomic molecules=== Hot nickel vapour reacting with other atoms in the gas phase can produce molecules consisting of two atoms. Nickel monofluoride can be observed by its [[emission spectrum]] in the gas phase.<ref name=muzangwa/>
Nickel subchloride NiCl is formed in gaseous form when nickel chloride is vapourised, and is the most common in the gas phase above 1450 K. It is formed when nickel is exposed to hot, low pressure [[chlorine]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Hauffe1 |first1=Karl |last2=Puschmann |first2=Herbert |title=Corrosion Handbook |chapter=A26 nickel |date=2008 |doi=10.1002/9783527610433.chb203030 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9783527610433.chb203030/abstract |publisher=Wiley}}</ref>
Nickel monobromide, NiBr can exist in the gas phase when an [[electric discharge]] goes through NiBr<sub>2</sub> gas.<ref name=muzangwa>{{cite journal |last1=Muzangwa |first1=L.G. |last2=Ayles |first2=V.L. |last3=Nyambo |first3=S. |last4=Reid |first4=S.A. |title=Probing the electronic structure of the nickel monohalides: Spectroscopy of the low-lying electronic states of NiBr and NiCl |journal=Journal of Molecular Spectroscopy |date=September 2011 |volume=269 |issue=1 |pages=36–40 |doi=10.1016/j.jms.2011.04.012|bibcode=2011JMoSp.269...36M }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Krishnamurty |first1=V. G. |title=The band spectrum of the diatomic molecule NiBr extending from 3930 to 5000 Å has been obtained in emission using a heavy current discharge |journal=Indian Journal of Physics and Proceedings of the Indian Association for the Cultivation of Science |date=16 April 1952 |volume=26 |page=429}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reddy |first1=S Paddi |last2=Rao |first2=P Tiruvenganna |title=The Band Spectra of NiCl and NiBr in the Visible |journal=Proceedings of the Physical Society |date=1 February 1960 |volume=75 |issue=2 |pages=275–279 |doi=10.1088/0370-1328/75/2/314|bibcode=1960PPS....75..275R }}</ref>
Nickelmonoiodide can exist in the gas phase.<ref name=muzangwa/>

==Alloys== Compounds of nickel with other metals can be called [[alloy]]s. The substances with fixed composition include [[nickel aluminide]] (NiAl) melting at 1638° with [[Hexagonal crystal system|hexagonal structure]].<ref name="CRC">{{cite book |editor1-last=Haynes |editor1-first=W. M. |title=CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics |date=2014 |isbn=9781482208672 |pages=4–77–4–78 |edition=95}}</ref> NiY, NiY<sub>3</sub>, Ni<sub>3</sub>Y, Ni<sub>4</sub>Y, NiGd<sub>3</sub>,<ref>{{cite web |title=Кристаллические структуры соединений Ni |url=http://www.kipt.kharkov.ua/kipt_sites/isspmst/crystal/ni/ni15.html |website=www.kipt.kharkov.ua}}</ref>
BaNi<sub>2</sub>Ge<sub>2</sub> changes structure from orthorhombic to tetragonal around 480 °C.<ref name=banige>{{cite journal |last1=Hlukhyy |first1=Viktor |last2=Trots |first2=Dmytro |last3=Fässler |first3=Thomas F. |title=First-Order Phase Transition in BaNi2Ge2 and the Influence of the Valence Electron Count on Distortion of the ThCr2 Si2 Structure Type |journal=Inorganic Chemistry |volume=56 |issue=3 |pages=1173 |date=13 January 2017 |doi=10.1021/acs.inorgchem.6b02190|pmid=28085271 }}</ref> THis is a ternary intermetallic compound. Others include BaNiSn<sub>3</sub> and the superconductors SrNi<sub>2</sub>Ge<sub>2</sub>, SrNi<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>, SrNi<sub>2</sub>As<sub>2</sub>, BaNi<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>, BaNi<sub>2</sub>As<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=banige/>
==Simple salts==
===Oxo acid salts=== [[File:Annabergite-20960.jpg|thumb|right|alt=bright green crystals in two clusters on a white and grey rock|Mint green Annabergite, a nickel arsenite]] Nickel(II) sulfate can crystallise with six water molecules yielding [[Retgersite]] or with seven making [[Morenosite]] which is isomorphic to Epsom salts. These contain the hexaquanickel(II) ion.<ref name=caw>{{cite book |title=Advanced Inorganic Chemistry: A Comprehensive Treatise |author=Cotton and Wilkinson |year=1966 |pages=878–893 |publisher=John Wiley & Sons}}</ref> There is also an anhydrous form, a dihydrate and a tetrahydrate, the last two crystallised from sulfuric acid. The hexahydrate has two forms, a blue tetragonal form, and a green monoclinic form, with a transition temperature around 53 °C.<ref>Mellor pp462-465</ref> The heptahydrate crystallises from water below 31.5 above this blue hexhydrate forms, and above 53.3 the green form.<ref>Mellor p 466-467</ref> Heating nickel sulfate dehydrates it, and then 700° it loses sulfur trioxide, sulfur dioxide and oxygen.
Nickel sulfite can be formed by bubbling sulfur dioxide through nickel carbonate suspended in water. A solution is formed that slowly loses sulfur dioxide, and which crystallises nickel sulfite hexahydrate. Crystals are frequently in the shape of stars, caused by the two opposite triangular [[enantiomorph]]s growing base to base. nickel sulfite hexahydrate is highly piezoelectric. Optically it is uniaxial negative with refractive indexes ω=1.552 ε=1.509.<ref name=Klasens/> When heated it dehydrates and then ends up making nickel oxide and nickel sulfate.<ref name="budk"/>
Nickel thiosulfate NiS<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> has the same structure as the magnesium salt. It has alternating layers of octahedral shaped nickel<sup>2+</sup> hexahydrate, and tetrahedral shaped S<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><sup>2−</sup> perpendicular to the β direction.<ref name=elerman/> When heated to 90 °C it decomposes to form NiS. NiS<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> can be made from BaS<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and NiSO<sub>4</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Elerman |first1=Y. |last2=Aydin Uraz |first2=A. |last3=Armagˇan |first3=N. |last4=Aka |first4=Y. |title=Crystal data for calcium and nickel thiosulphate hexahydrates: CaS2O3.6H2O and NiS2O3.6H2O |journal=Journal of Applied Crystallography |date=1 August 1977 |volume=10 |issue=4 |pages=362–363 |doi=10.1107/S0021889877013673}}</ref> Nickel sulfamate can be used for nickel or mixed nickel-tungsten plating.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Eliaz |first1=N. |last2=Sridhar |first2=T.M. |last3=Gileadi |first3=E. |title=Synthesis and characterization of nickel tungsten alloys by electrodeposition |journal=Electrochimica Acta |date=May 2005 |volume=50 |issue=14 |pages=2893–2904 |doi=10.1016/j.electacta.2004.11.038}}</ref> It can be formed by the action of sulfamic acid on nickel carbonate.<ref name=anger/>
[[Nickel selenite]] NiSeO<sub>3</sub> has many different hydrates, anhydrous NiSeO<sub>3</sub>•{{frac|1|3}}H<sub>2</sub>O, NiSeO<sub>3</sub>•H<sub>2</sub>O, NiSeO<sub>3</sub>•2H<sub>2</sub>O (which is also a mineral called [[ahlfeldite]]), and NiSeO<sub>3</sub>•4H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=Vlaev>{{cite journal |last1=Vlaev |first1=L. T. |last2=Genieva |first2=Svetlana D. |last3=Georgieva |first3=Velyana G. |title=Study of the crystallization fields of nickel(II) selenites in the system NiSeO3–SeO2–H2O |journal=Journal of Thermal Analysis and Calorimetry |date=16 May 2006 |volume=86 |issue=2 |pages=449–456 |doi=10.1007/s10973-005-7397-x}}</ref>
[[Nickel nitrate]] commonly crystallises with six water molecules,<ref name=caw/> but can also be anhydrous, or with two, four or nine waters.<ref name=Ullmann>Keith Lascelles, Lindsay G. Morgan, David Nicholls, Detmar Beyersmann, "Nickel Compounds" in Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry Wiley-VCH, Weinheim, 2005. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a17_235.pub2}}</ref> triphenylphosphine oxide nickel nitrate [(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>6</sub>)<sub>3</sub>PO]<sub>2</sub>Ni(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is non ionic, with nitrato as a ligand. It can be made from nickel perchlorate. It is yellow and melts at 266 °C.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bannister |first1=E. |last2=Cotton |first2=F. A. |title=456. Phosphine oxide complexes. Part III. Bis(triphenylphosphine oxide)dinitrato-complexes of cobalt(II), nickel(II), copper(II), and zinc(II) |journal=Journal of the Chemical Society (Resumed) |date=1960 |pages=2276 |doi=10.1039/JR9600002276}}</ref>
[[Nickel carbonate]] NiCO<sub>3</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O, [[hellyerite]],<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Isaacs |first1=T. |title=The mineralogy and chemistry of the nickel carbonates |journal=Mineralogical Magazine |date=7 November 1963 |volume=33 |issue=263 |pages=663–678 |url=http://www.minersoc.org/pages/Archive-MM/Volume_33/33-263-663.pdf |accessdate=10 June 2016|bibcode=1963MinM...33..663I |doi=10.1180/minmag.1963.033.263.04 }}</ref> crystallising with six water molecules, precipitates when an alkali bicarbonate is added to a Ni aqueous solution.<ref name=caw/> Basic nickel carbonate, [[zaratite]], with the formula Ni<sub>4</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>(OH)<sub>6</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>, is produced when alkali carbonates are added to a nickel solution. [[Nickel phosphate]], Ni<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•7H<sub>2</sub>O is also insoluble.<ref name=caw/> A number of other phosphates have been made, including [[nanoporous]] substances resembling [[zeolites]] named with "Versailles Santa Barbara" or VSB. The nanoporous nickel phosphates can accommodate sufficiently small molecules and selectively catalyse reactions on them.<ref name="Timofeeva"/> A [[nickel arsenate]], Ni<sub>3</sub>(AsO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·8H<sub>2</sub>O occurs as the mineral [[annabergite]].<ref name=Mindat>[http://www.mindat.org/min-240.html Mindat.org]</ref>
Nickel perchlorate, Ni(ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O,<ref name=caw/> nickel chlorate, Ni(ClO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lutz |first1=H.D |last2=Suchanek |first2=E |title=Intramolecular coupling of BrO stretching vibrations in solid bromates, infrared and Raman spectroscopic studies on M(BrO3)2·6H2O (M=Mg, Co, Ni, Zn) and Ni(ClO3)2·6H2O |journal=Spectrochimica Acta Part A |date=December 2000 |volume=56 |issue=14 |pages=2707–2713 |doi=10.1016/S1386-1425(00)00310-3|bibcode=2000AcSpA..56.2707L }}</ref>[[nickel chromate]] (NiCrO<sub>4</sub>), nickel chromite (NiCr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub>), [[nickel(II) titanate]], [[nickel bromate]] Ni(BrO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Blackburn |first1=AC |last2=Gallucci |first2=JC |last3=Gerkin |first3=RE |title=Structure of hexaaquanickel(II) bromate. |journal=Acta Crystallographica Section C |date=15 September 1991 |volume=47 |pages=1786–1789 |pmid=1786165 |issue=9 |doi=10.1107/s0108270191002196}}</ref> nickel iodate (Ni(IO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•4H<sub>2</sub>O), nickel stannate (NiSnO<sub>3</sub>•2H<sub>2</sub>O)<ref name="CRC"/> are some other oxy-salts.
The uranates include NiU<sub>2</sub>O<sub>6</sub>,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Pies |first1=W. |title=Key Elements: D9-, d10-, d1_d3-, f-Elements |volume=7e |last2=Weiss |first2=A. |date=1976 |pages=91–94 |doi=10.1007/10201569_22|chapter=e517, XVI.4.3.1 Simple oxo-compounds of uranium (oxouranates), XVI.4.3.2 Simple oxo-compounds of uranium with H2O (oxouranates with H2O) |series=Landolt-Börnstein - Group III Condensed Matter |isbn=3-540-07334-5 }}</ref> NiUO<sub>4</sub> α and β forms (orthorhombic a=6.415 Å; b=6.435 Å; c=6.835 Å),<ref name=niu>{{cite journal |last1=Young |first1=A. P. |title=Nickel Orthouronate: High-Pressure Synthesis |journal=Science |date=16 September 1966 |volume=153 |issue=3742 |pages=1380–1381 |doi=10.1126/science.153.3742.1380|bibcode=1966Sci...153.1380Y }}</ref> and NiU<sub>3</sub>O<sub>10.</sub><ref name=niu/>

===Fluoro acid salts=== Nickel tetrafluoroborate, Ni(BF<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O is very soluble in water, alcohol and acetonitrile. It is prepared by dissolving [[nickel carbonate]] in [[tetrafluoroboric acid]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=O'Brien |first1=James F. |last2=Reynolds |first2=Warren Lind |title=Nuclear magnetic resonance study of cobalt and nickel tetrafluoroborates |journal=Inorganic Chemistry |date=November 1967 |volume=6 |issue=11 |pages=2110–2111 |doi=10.1021/ic50057a041}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Ryss |first1=A. I. |last2=Radchenko |first2=I. V. |title=X-ray study of aqueous solutions of nickel tetrafluoroborate |journal=Journal of Structural Chemistry |date=1966 |volume=6 |issue=4 |pages=489–492 |doi=10.1007/BF00744813}}</ref> Nickel tetrafluoroberyllate NiBeF<sub>4</sub>•''x''H<sub>2</sub>O, can be hydrated with six or seven water molecules.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rây |first1=Nirmalendu Nath |title=Fluoberyllate und ihre Analogie mit den Sulfaten. II. Fluoberyllate einiger zweiwertiger Metalle |journal=Zeitschrift für anorganische und allgemeine Chemie |date=20 April 1932 |volume=205 |issue=3 |pages=257–267 |doi=10.1002/zaac.19322050307}}</ref> Both nickel [[hexafluorostannate]] <chem>NiSnF6.6H2O</chem> and nickel [[fluorosilicate]] <chem>NiSnF6.6H2O</chem> crystallise in the trigonal system.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Karnezos |first1=M. |last2=Friedberg |first2=S. A. |title=FERROMAGNETISM IN NiSnF6.6H2O AND NiSiF6.6H2O |journal=Le Journal de Physique Colloques |date=August 1978 |volume=39 |issue=C6 |pages=C6–814–C6–815 |doi=10.1051/jphyscol:19786362 |url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/jpa-00217826/document |accessdate=14 May 2016}}</ref> Nickel hexafluorogermanate NiGeF<sub>6</sub> has a rosy-tan colour and a hexagonal crystal with a = 5.241 Å unit cell volume is 92.9 Å<sup>3</sup>. It is formed in the reaction with GeF<sub>4</sub> and K<sub>2</sub>NiF<sub>6</sub>.<ref name=Chacon/> Nickel fuorotitanate <chem>NiTiF6.6H2O</chem> crystallises in hexagonal green crystals. It can be made by dissolving nickel carbonate, and titanium dioxide in hydrofluoric acid. The crystal dimensions are a = 9.54, c = 9.91 density = 2.09 (measure 2.03).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Davidovich |first1=R. L. |last2=Kaidalova |first2=T. A. |last3=Levchishina |first3=T. F. |title=X-ray diffraction data for some divalent metal fluorotitanates |journal=Journal of Structural Chemistry |date=1971 |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=166–168 |doi=10.1007/BF00744565}}</ref>
Ni(AsF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Ni(SbF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub>, Ni(BiF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub> are made by reacting the hexafluoro acid with NiF<sub>2</sub> in [[hydrofluoric acid]].<ref name=Chacon>{{cite web |last1=Chacon |first1=Lisa Carine |title=The Synthesis, Characterization and Reactivity of High Oxidation State Nickel Fluorides |url=https://publications.lbl.gov/islandora/object/ir%3A112067/datastream/PDF/download/citation.pdf |publisher=University of California |accessdate=27 April 2016 |location=Berkeley California |date=December 1997}}</ref> They all have hexagonal crystal structure, resembling the similar salts of the other first row transition metals.<ref name=Chacon/> For Ni(AsF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub> a = 4.98, c = 26.59, and V = 571, formula weight Z=3.<ref name=Chacon/> Ni(SbF<sub>6</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is yellow with a = 5.16Å, c = 27.90Å Z = 3. The structure resembles LiSbF<sub>6</sub>, but with every second metal along the c axis missing.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Christe |first1=Karl O. |last2=Wilson |first2=William W. |last3=Bougon |first3=Roland A. |last4=Charpin |first4=Pierrette |title=Preparation and characterization of Ni(SbF6)2 |journal=Journal of Fluorine Chemistry |date=January 1987 |volume=34 |issue=3–4 |pages=287–298 |doi=10.1016/S0022-1139(00)85173-8}}</ref>
Others include the green fluorohafnate NiHfF<sub>6</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O, and Ni<sub>2</sub>HfF<sub>8</sub>•12H<sub>2</sub>O,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Davidovich |first1=R. L. |last2=Buslaev |first2=Yu. A. |last3=Levchishina |first3=T. F. |title=Synthesis of some new fluorohafnate complexes |journal=Bulletin of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR Division of Chemical Science |date=March 1968 |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=676–676 |doi=10.1007/BF00911649}}</ref> NiZrF<sub>6</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Karnezos |first1=M. |last2=Meier |first2=D. |last3=Friedberg |first3=S. A. |title=Magnetic ordering in NiZrF6⋅6H20 |journal=AIP Conference Proceedings |date=9–12 December 1975 |volume=29 |page=505 |doi=10.1063/1.30416|bibcode=1976AIPC...29..505K }}</ref>
===Chloroacid salts=== Nickel tetrachloroiodate Ni(ICl<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub> can be made by reacting iodine with nickel chloride. It consists of green needles.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Weinland |first1=R. F. |last2=Schlegelmilch |first2=Fr. |title=Über Doppelsalze des Jodtrichlorids mit Chloriden zweiwertiger Metalle |journal=Zeitschrift für anorganische Chemie |date=7 March 1902 |volume=30 |issue=1 |pages=134–143 |doi=10.1002/zaac.19020300109}}</ref>
===Nitrogen anion salts=== [[Nickel cyanide]] tetrahydrate Ni(CN)<sub>2</sub>•4H<sub>2</sub>O is insoluble in water, but dissolves in aqueous ammonia.<ref name="CRC"/> It forms double salts with interesting structures.<ref name="hibble">{{cite journal |last1=Hibble |first1=Simon J. |last2=Chippindale |first2=Ann M. |last3=Pohl |first3=Alexander H. |last4=Hannon |first4=Alex C. |title=Surprises from a Simple Material—The Structure and Properties of Nickel Cyanide |journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition |date=17 September 2007 |volume=46 |issue=37 |pages=7116–7118 |doi=10.1002/anie.200701246}}</ref>
Nickel azide Ni(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is a sensitive explosive. It can be made by treating nickel carbonate with [[hydrazoic acid]]. Acetone causes the precipitation of the hydrous solid salt, which is green. At 490K it slowly decomposes to nitrogen and nickel metal powder, losing a half of the nitrogen in four hours.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Sood |first1=R. K. |last2=Nya |first2=A. E. |last3=Etim |first3=E. S. |title=Thermal decomposition of nickel azide |journal=Journal of Thermal Analysis |date=December 1981 |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=231–237 |doi=10.1007/BF01915269}}</ref> Nickel azide is complexed by one azo group when dissolved in water, but in other solvents, the nickel atom can have up to four azo groups attached.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Abu-Eittah |first1=R. |last2=Elmakabaty |first2=S. |title=Spectra of Nickel(II)-Azide Complexes in Organic Solvents |journal=Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan |date=1973 |volume=46 |issue=11 |pages=3427–3431 |doi=10.1246/bcsj.46.3427}}</ref> Nickel azide forms a dihydrate: Ni(N<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>•2H<sub>2</sub>O and a basic salt called nickel hydroxy azide Ni(OH)N<sub>3</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=IROM |first1=I I |title=Photolysis of nickel hydroxy azide. |journal=Global Journal of Pure and Applied Sciences |date=1 January 2001 |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=73–80 |doi=10.4314/gjpas.v7i1.16208}}</ref>
Nickel amide, Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub> is a deep red compound that contains Ni<sub>6</sub> clusters surrounded by 12 NH<sub>2</sub> groups.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tenten |first1=A. |last2=Jacobs |first2=H. |title=Isolierte Ni6(NH2)12-Einheiten in Nickel(II)-Amid |journal=Journal of the Less Common Metals |date=June 1991 |volume=170 |issue=1 |pages=145–159 |doi=10.1016/0022-5088(91)90060-H}}</ref> Nickel amide also forms a series of double salts. Other homoleptic nickel amides derived by substituting the hydrogen atoms are Ni[N(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub> (diphenyl) and boryl amides Ni[NBMes<sub>2</sub>Mes]<sub>2</sub> and Ni[NBMes<sub>2</sub>C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>]<sub>2</sub>.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Lappert |first1=Michael |title=Metal amide chemistry |date=2009 |publisher=Wiley |location=Chichester, U.K. |isbn=9780470721841 |pages=172–173}}</ref>
===Organic acid salts=== [[Nickel acetate]] has the formula (CH<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>2</sub>Ni·4H<sub>2</sub>O. It has monodentate acetate and hydrogen bonding. A dihdrate also exists. Nickel acetate is used to seal [[anodised aluminium]].<ref name=Downie>{{cite journal |last1=Downie |first1=T. C. |last2=Harrison |first2=W. |last3=Raper |first3=E. S. |last4=Hepworth |first4=M. A. |title=A three-dimensional study of the crystal structure of nickel acetate tetrahydrate |journal=Acta Crystallographica Section B |date=15 March 1971 |volume=27 |issue=3 |pages=706–712 |doi=10.1107/S0567740871002802}}</ref>
Nickel [[formate]] <chem>Ni(HCOO)2.2H2O</chem> decomposes when heated to yield carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, hydrogen, water and finely divided porous nickel.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=FOX |first1=P |title=The development of internal structure during thermal decomposition: Nickel formate dihydrate |journal=Journal of Catalysis |date=January 1971 |volume=20 |issue=1 |pages=67–73 |doi=10.1016/0021-9517(71)90007-8}}</ref> All the nickel atoms are six coordinated, but half have four water molecules and two formate oxygens close to the atom, and the other half are coordinated by six oxygens of formate groups.<ref name=Krogmann>{{cite journal |last1=Krogmann |first1=Klaus |last2=Mattes |first2=Rainer |title=Die Kristallstruktur von Nickelformiat, Ni(HCOO)2, 2H2O |journal=Zeitschrift für Kristallographie - Crystalline Materials |date=January 1963 |volume=118 |issue=1–6 |doi=10.1524/zkri.1963.118.16.291 |language=de}}</ref>
''[[Aspergillus niger]]'' is able to dispose of otherwise toxic levels of nickel in its environment by forming [[nickel oxalate]] dihydrate crystals.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Magyarosy |first1=A. |last2=Laidlaw |first2=R. |last3=Kilaas |first3=R. |last4=Echer |first4=C. |last5=Clark |first5=D. |last6=Keasling |first6=J. |title=Nickel accumulation and nickel oxalate precipitation by Aspergillus niger |journal=Applied Microbiology and Biotechnology |date=1 July 2002 |volume=59 |issue=2–3 |pages=382–388 |doi=10.1007/s00253-002-1020-x}}</ref> nickel oxalate can also be formed in to various namorods and nanofibres by use of surfacants.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vaidya |first1=Sonalika |last2=Rastogi |first2=Pankaj |last3=Agarwal |first3=Suman |last4=Gupta |first4=Santosh K. |last5=Ahmad |first5=Tokeer |last6=Antonelli |first6=Anthony M. |last7=Ramanujachary |first7=K. V. |last8=Lofland |first8=S. E. |last9=Ganguli |first9=Ashok K. |title=Nanospheres, Nanocubes, and Nanorods of Nickel Oxalate: Control of Shape and Size by Surfactant and Solvent |journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry C |date=August 2008 |volume=112 |issue=33 |pages=12610–12615 |doi=10.1021/jp803575h}}</ref> When heated nickel oxalate dihydrate dehydrates at 258° and decomposes to NiO over 316 °C.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zhan |first1=Dan |last2=Cong |first2=Changjie |last3=Diakite |first3=Kahirou |last4=Tao |first4=Youtian |last5=Zhang |first5=Keli |title=Kinetics of thermal decomposition of nickel oxalate dihydrate in air |journal=Thermochimica Acta |date=June 2005 |volume=430 |issue=1–2 |pages=101–105 |doi=10.1016/j.tca.2005.01.029 |url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0040603105000626}}</ref> Double oxalate salts where [[oxalate]] is a ligand on the nickel atom may be called [[oxalatonickelate]]s.
Other organic acid salts of nickel include nickel oleate, nickel propionate, nickel butyrate, nickel caprylate, nickel lactate, nickel benzoate, nickel bis(acetyl acetonate), nickel salicylate, nickel alkyl phenyl salicylate. Nickel stearate forms a green solution, however when precipitated with alcohol a gel is produced, that also contains a mixture of basic salts, and free stearic acid.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Soyenkoff |first1=Basil |title=Benzene Dispersions of Basic Soaps of Nickel and Iron |journal=Journal of Physical Chemistry |date=January 1929 |volume=34 |issue=11 |pages=2519–2538 |doi=10.1021/j150317a006}}</ref>
Nickel malonate, and nickel hydrogen malonate both crystallise with two molecules of water. They decomposes when heated to yield gaseous water, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, ethanol, acetic acid, [[methyl formate]] and [[ethyl formate]]. Nickel acetate exists as an intermediate and the final result is that solid nickel, nickel oxide, Ni<sub>3</sub>C and carbon remain.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mohamed |first1=Mohamed A |last2=Galwey |first2=Andrew K |last3=Halawy |first3=Samih A |title=Kinetic and thermodynamic studies of the non-isothermal decompositions of nickel malonate dihydrate and nickel hydrogen malonate dihydrate |journal=Thermochimica Acta |date=December 1998 |volume=323 |issue=1–2 |pages=27–36 |doi=10.1016/S0040-6031(98)00492-4}}</ref> With malonate nickel can form a bis-malonato-nickelate anion, which can form double salts.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Xiao |first1=Xunwen |last2=Xu |first2=Wei |last3=Li |first3=Yan |last4=Zhang |first4=Bin |last5=Zhu |first5=Daoben |title=Dipotassium diaquabis(malonato-κ2O,O')nickelate(II) dihydrate |journal=Acta Crystallographica Section E |date=12 December 2003 |volume=60 |issue=1 |pages=m48–m49 |doi=10.1107/S1600536803027508}}</ref> Nickel maleate can be made from [[maleic acid]] and nickel carbonate in boiling water. A dihydrate crystallises from the water solution.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McGinn |first1=M. J. |last2=Wheeler |first2=B. R. |last3=Galwey |first3=A. K. |title=Thermal decomposition of nickel maleate |journal=Transactions of the Faraday Society |date=1971 |volume=67 |pages=1480 |doi=10.1039/TF9716701480}}</ref> Nickel fumarate prepared from [[fumaric acid]] and nickel carbonate is pale green as a tetrahydrate, and mustard coloured as an anhydride. It decomposes when heated to 300° to 340° in vacuum. Decomposition mostly produces nickel carbide, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide and methane. But also produced were butanes, benzene, toluene, and organic acid.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=McGinn |first1=M. J. |last2=Wheeler |first2=B. R. |last3=Galwey |first3=A. K. |title=Thermal decomposition of nickel fumarate |journal=Transactions of the Faraday Society |date=1970 |volume=66 |pages=1809 |doi=10.1039/TF9706601809}}</ref>
[[Nickel succinate]] can form [[metal organic framework]] compounds.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Guillou |first1=Nathalie |last2=Livage |first2=Carine |last3=Férey |first3=Gérard |title=Cobalt and Nickel Oxide Architectures in Metal Carboxylate Frameworks: From Coordination Polymers to 3D Inorganic Skeletons |journal=European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry |date=December 2006 |volume=2006 |issue=24 |pages=4963–4978 |doi=10.1002/ejic.200600663}}</ref>
[[Nickel citrate]] complexes are found in leaves of some nickel accumulating plant species in New Caledonia such as ''[[Pycnandra acuminata]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Lee |first1=Julian |last2=Reeves |first2=Roger D. |last3=Brooks |first3=Robert R. |last4=Jaffré |first4=Tanguy |title=The relation between nickel and citric acid in some nickel-accumulating plants |journal=Phytochemistry |date=January 1978 |volume=17 |issue=6 |pages=1033–1035 |doi=10.1016/S0031-9422(00)94274-2}}</ref> Citrate complexes include NiHcit, NiHcit<sub>2</sub><sup>3−</sup>, Nicit<sup>−</sup>, Nicit<sub>2</sub><sup>4−</sup>, and Ni<sub>2</sub>H<sub>2</sub>cit<sub>2</sub><sup>4−</sup>. (ordered from low to high pH). Also there is Ni<sub>4</sub>H<sub>4</sub>cit<sub>3</sub><sup>5−</sup>. Nickel citrate is important in nickel plating.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rode |first1=Sabine |last2=Henninot |first2=Christophe |last3=Matlosz |first3=Michael |title=Complexation Chemistry in Nickel and Copper-Nickel Alloy Plating from Citrate Baths |journal=Journal of the Electrochemical Society |date=2005 |volume=152 |issue=4 |pages=C248 |doi=10.1149/1.1869980}}</ref> When precipitation of nickel citrate is attempted a gel forms. This apparently consists of tangled fibres of [(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)Ni]<sub>n</sub>, which can be reduced to nickel metal fibres less than a micron thick, and meters long.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Shen |first1=Xiangqian |last2=Jing |first2=Maoxiang |last3=Wang |first3=Taoping |last4=Cao |first4=Kai |title=Preparation of Superfine Ni and Fe Fibers by the Organic Gel-Thermal Reduction Method |journal=Rare Metal Materials and Engineering |date=June 2006 |url=http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-COSE200606023.htm}}</ref> Double nickel citrates exist, including tetraanion citrate when pH is over 9.5.<ref name="wang7">{{cite journal |last1=Wang |first1=Lian-Ying |last2=Wu |first2=Guo-Qing |last3=Evans |first3=David G. |title=Synthesis and characterization of a layered double hydroxide containing an intercalated nickel(II) citrate complex |journal=Materials Chemistry and Physics |date=July 2007 |volume=104 |issue=1 |pages=133–140 |doi=10.1016/j.matchemphys.2007.02.098}}</ref> An amorphous nickel iron citrate Ni<sub>3</sub>Fe<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>8</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O produces carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide and acetone when heated over 200 °C leaving [[Trevorite]], NiFe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> a nickel [[Ferrite (magnet)|ferrite]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gajbhiye |first1=N.S. |last2=Prasad |first2=Seema |title=Thermal decomposition of hexahydrated nickel iron citrate |journal=Thermochimica Acta |date=August 1996 |volume=285 |issue=2 |pages=325–336 |doi=10.1016/0040-6031(96)02906-1}}</ref> A green crystalline nickel citrate with formula Ni<sub>3</sub>(C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O melts at 529K and decomposition starts at 333K.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Masłowska |first1=J. |title=Thermal decomposition and thermofracto-chromatographic studies of metal citrates |journal=Journal of Thermal Analysis |date=September 1984 |volume=29 |issue=5 |pages=895–904 |doi=10.1007/BF02188835}}</ref>
[[Nickel glutarate]] in the form called Mil-77, [Ni<sub>20</sub>{(C<sub>5</sub>H<sub>6</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)<sub>20</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>}]⋅40H<sub>2</sub>O is pale green. It crystallises in a porous structure containing twenty member rings. The 40 water molecules "occluded" in the porous channels come out when it is heated to 150 °C retaining the crystal framework. At 240 °C the crystal form changes and over 255° the remaining water is lost. Between 330° and 360° the organic components burn and it is destroyed.<ref name=Guillou003>{{cite journal |last1=Guillou |first1=Nathalie |last2=Livage |first2=Carine |last3=Drillon |first3=Marc |last4=Férey |first4=Gérard |title=The Chirality, Porosity, and Ferromagnetism of a 3D Nickel Glutarate with Intersecting 20-Membered Ring Channels |journal=Angewandte Chemie International Edition |date=10 November 2003 |volume=42 |issue=43 |pages=5314–5317 |doi=10.1002/anie.200352520}}</ref>
[[Cyclopropane carboxylic acid]] forms two basic salts with nickel, a hydrate Ni<sub>9</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>(C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>5</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)8·2H<sub>2</sub>O with density 1.554 Mg/m<sup>3</sup> and an anhydrous form Ni<sub>5</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>(C<sub>4</sub>H<sub>5</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)<sub>8</sub> with density 2.172 mg/m<sup>3</sup>.<ref name=forster03>{{cite journal |last1=Forster |first1=Paul M |last2=Yang |first2=Zuag |last3=Cheetham |first3=Anthony K |title=Open framework metal monocarboxylates: nickel cyclopropionates containing 16- and 18-membered rings |journal=Solid State Sciences |date=April 2003 |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=635–642 |doi=10.1016/S1293-2558(03)00055-4|bibcode=2003SSSci...5..635F }}</ref>
Nickel trifluoroacetate tetrahydrate exists, as well as two emerald green acid trifluoroacetates, a bridged trinuclear form [Ni<sub>3</sub>(CF<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>6</sub>(CF<sub>3</sub>COOH)<sub>6</sub>](CF<sub>3</sub>COOH) and a hydrated acid form [Ni<sub>3</sub>(CF<sub>3</sub>COO)<sub>6</sub>(CF<sub>3</sub>COOH)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>](CF<sub>3</sub>COOH)<sub>2</sub> both with triclinic crystal form. The first has density 2.205 and the second 2.124. They are made by dissolving the nickel trifluoroacetate tetrahydrate in [[trifluoroacetic acid]] either anhydrous or 1% hydrated.<ref name=Tokareva>{{cite journal |last1=Tokareva |first1=A. O. |last2=Tereshchenko |first2=D. S. |last3=Boltalin |first3=A. I. |last4=Troyanov |first4=S. I. |title=Acid Co(II) and Ni(II) trifluoroacetate complexes: Synthesis and crystal structure |journal=Russian Journal of Coordination Chemistry |date=September 2006 |volume=32 |issue=9 |pages=663–668 |doi=10.1134/S1070328406090077}}</ref>
[[Nickel naphthenate]] is used as a fuel additive to suppress smoke,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=SALOOJA |first1=K. C. |title=Burner Fuel Additives* |journal=Combustion Science and Technology |date=March 1972 |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=243–249 |doi=10.1080/00102207208952528}}</ref> as a rubber catalyst and as an oil additive.
When [[Nickel benzoate]] is heated in a vacuum, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, [[benzene]], [[benzoic acid]], [[phenol]], [[biphenyl]], nickel, nickel oxide, and nickel carbide are formed.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Galwey |first1=A. K. |title=1152. The thermal decomposition of nickel benzoate and of the nickel salt of cyclohexanecarboxylic acid |journal=Journal of the Chemical Society |date=1965 |pages=6188 |doi=10.1039/JR9650006188}}</ref> It can crystallise as anhydrous, a trihydrate or a tetrahydrate.<ref name=vrab/>
Nickel terephthalate can be made by a double decomposition of sodium terephthalate and nickel nitrate. Nickel terephthalate precipitates. Its solubility is 0.38 g/100g water at 25 °C. In ammonium hydroxide a violet solution forms. Boiling acetic acid converts the nickel to nickel acetate. The terephthalate converts to a basic salt when boiled in water. Understating this compound is important when reducing coloured contaminants in polymers made from terephthalate.<ref name="sherif">{{cite journal |last1=Sherif |first1=Fawzy G. |title=Heavy Metal Terephthalates |journal=Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Product Research and Development |date=1 September 1970 |volume=9 |issue=3 |pages=408–412 |doi=10.1021/i360035a026}}</ref>

==Double salts== Nickel is one of the metals that can form [[Tutton's salts]]. The singly charged ion can be any of the full range of potassium, rubidium, cesium, ammonium (NH4), or thallium.<ref name="Wang2008">{{cite journal |last=Wang |first=Xia |author2=Xinxin Zhuang |author3=Genbo Su |author4=Youping He |year=2008 |title=A new ultraviolet filter: Rb2Ni (SO4)2·6H2O (RNSH) single crystal |journal=Optical Materials |volume=31 |issue=2 |pages=233–236 |issn=0925-3467 |doi=10.1016/j.optmat.2008.03.020 |url=http://ir.fjirsm.ac.cn/bitstream/350002/5857/1/Wang-2008-A%20new%20ultraviolet%20fi.pdf|bibcode=2008OptMa..31..233W }}</ref> As a mineral the ammonium nickel salt, (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·6 H<sub>2</sub>O, can be called nickelboussingaultite.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nickelboussingaultite: Nickelboussingaultite mineral information and data. |url=http://www.mindat.org/min-2896.html |website=www.mindat.org |accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> With sodium, the double sulfate is nickelblödite Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·4 H<sub>2</sub>O from the [[blödite family]]. Nickel can be substituted by other divalent metals of similar sized to make mixtures that crystallise in the same form.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nickelblödite: Nickelblödite mineral information and data. |url=http://www.mindat.org/min-2890.html |website=www.mindat.org |accessdate=4 May 2016}}</ref>
Nickel forms double salts with Tutton's salt structure with [[tetrafluoroberyllate]] with the range of cations of ammonia,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Montgomery |first1=H. |title=Diammonium nickel bis(tetrafluoroberyllate)hexahydrate |journal=Acta Crystallographica Section B |date=15 September 1980 |volume=36 |issue=9 |pages=2121–2123 |doi=10.1107/S0567740880008060}}</ref> potassium, rubidium, cesium,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Rây |first1=Nirmalendunath |title=Fluoberyllate und ihre Analogie mit Sulfaten. IV. Doppelsalze mit Rubidium- und Cäsiumfluoberyllaten |journal=Zeitschrift für anorganische und allgemeine Chemie |date=18 April 1936 |volume=227 |issue=1 |pages=32–36 |language=de |doi=10.1002/zaac.19362270105}}</ref> and thallium.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bose |first1=A. |last2=Mitra |first2=S. C. |last3=Datta |first3=S. K. |title=The Behaviour of the Paramagnetic Ions in the Single Crystals of Some Similarly Constituted Salts of the Iron Group of Elements. II. Hydrated NiFormula Salts |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society A |date=11 November 1958 |volume=248 |issue=1253 |pages=153–168 |doi=10.1098/rspa.1958.0236|bibcode=1958RSPSA.248..153B }}</ref>
Anhydrous salts of the formula M<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, which can be termed metal nickel triusulfates, belong to the family of [[langbeinites]]. The known salts include (NH<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, K<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> and Rb<sub>2</sub>Ni<sub>2</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, and those of Tl and Cs are predicted to exist.
Some minerals are double salts, for example [[Nickelzippeite]] Ni<sub>2</sub>(UO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>6</sub>(SO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>(OH)<sub>10</sub> · 16H<sub>2</sub>O which is isomorphic to [[cobaltzippeite]], [[magnesiozippeite]] and [[zinczippeite]], part of the [[zippeite]] group.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nickelzippeite: Nickelzippeite mineral information and data. |url=http://www.mindat.org/min-2898.html |website=www.mindat.org |accessdate=10 May 2016}}</ref>
Double hydrides of nickel exist, such as Mg<sub>2</sub>NiH<sub>4</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Reilly |first1=James J. |last2=Wiswall |first2=Richard H. |title=Reaction of hydrogen with alloys of magnesium and nickel and the formation of Mg2NiH4 |journal=Inorganic Chemistry |date=November 1968 |volume=7 |issue=11 |pages=2254–2256 |doi=10.1021/ic50069a016}}</ref>

Double fluorides include the above-mentioned fluoroanion salts, and those [[fluoronickelate]]s such as NiF<sub>4</sub> and NiF<sub>6</sub>. Other odd ones include an apple green coloured KNiF<sub>3</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O and NaNiF<sub>3</sub>·H<sub>2</sub>O, aluminium nickel pentafluoride AlNiF<sub>5</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, ceric nickelous decafluoride Ce<sub>2</sub>NiF<sub>10</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, niobium nickel fluoride Ni<sub>3</sub>H<sub>4</sub>Nb<sub>2</sub>F<sub>20</sub>·19H<sub>2</sub>O, vanadium nickel pentafluoride VNiF<sub>5</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, vanadyl nickel tetrafluoride VONiF<sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, chromic nickelous pentafluoride CrNiF<sub>5</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, molybdenum nickel dioxytetrafluoride NiMoO<sub>2</sub>F<sub>4</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O, tungsten nickel dioxytetrafluoride NiWO<sub>2</sub>F<sub>4</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O and NiWO<sub>2</sub>F<sub>4</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O, manganic nickel pentafluoride MnNiF<sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O, nickelous ferric fluoride FeNiF<sub>5</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref>Mellor 405-406</ref>
Nickel trichloride double salts exist which are polymers. Nickel is in octahedral coordination, with double halogen bridges. Examples of this include RbNiCl<sub>3</sub>, pinkish tan coloured H<sub>2</sub>NN(CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>NiCl<sub>3</sub>.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Goedken |first1=V. L. |last2=Vallarino |first2=L. M. |last3=Quagliano |first3=J. V. |title=Cationic ligands. Coordination of the 1,1,1-trimethylhydrazinium cation to nickel(II) |journal=Inorganic Chemistry |date=December 1971 |volume=10 |issue=12 |pages=2682–2685 |doi=10.1021/ic50106a011}}</ref> Other double trichlorides include potassium nickel trichloride KNiCl<sub>3</sub>·5H<sub>2</sub>O,<ref name=m419/> yellow cesium nickel trichloride CsNiCl<sub>3</sub>,<ref name=m419/> lithium nickel trichloride LiNiCl<sub>3</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O,<ref name=m419/> hyrdrazinium nickel tetrachloride,<ref name=m419/> and nickel ammonium chloride hexahydrate NH<sub>4</sub>NiCl<sub>3</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name="CRC"/>
The [[tetrachloronickelates]] contain a tetrahedral NiCl<sub>4</sub><sup>2−</sup> and are dark blue. Some salts of organic bases are ionic liquids at [[standard conditions]].<ref name="Meredith">{{cite journal |last1=Meredith |first1=M. Brett |last2=McMillen |first2=C. Heather |last3=Goodman |first3=Jonathan T. |last4=Hanusa |first4=Timothy P. |title=Ambient temperature imidazolium-based ionic liquids with tetrachloronickelate(II) anions |journal=Polyhedron |date=August 2009 |volume=28 |issue=12 |pages=2355–2358 |doi=10.1016/j.poly.2009.04.037}}</ref> tetramethylammonium nickel trichloride is pink and very insoluble.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cotton |first1=F. A. |last2=Faut |first2=O. D. |last3=Goodgame |first3=D. M. L. |title=Preparation, Spectra and Electronic Structures of Tetrahedral Nickel(II) Complexes Containing Triphenylphosphine and Halide Ions as Ligands |journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society |date=January 1961 |volume=83 |issue=2 |pages=344–351 |doi=10.1021/ja01463a021}}</ref> Other tetrachlorides include rubidium nickel tetrachloride, lithium nickel tetrachloride Li<sub>2</sub>NiCl<sub>4</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O stable from 23 to 60°, stannous nickel tetrachloride <chem>SnCl2.NiCl2.6H2O</chem>, stannic nickel hexachloride <chem>SnCl4.NiCl2.6H2O</chem> is tetragonal.<ref name=m420/>
Lithium nickel hexachloride Li<sub>4</sub>NiCl<sub>6</sub>·10H<sub>2</sub>O is stable from 0 to 23°.
Copper nickel dioxychloride 2CuO·NiCl<sub>2</sub>·6H<sub>2</sub>O, and copper nickel trioxychloride 3CuO·NiCl<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=m419>Mellor p419</ref>
Cadmium dinickel hexachloride, <chem>CdCl2.2NiCl2.12H2O</chem> crystallises in hexagonal system, dicadmium dinickel hexachloride, <chem>2CdCl2.NiCl2.12H2O</chem> has rhombic crystals, and is [[pleochroic]] varying from light to dark green.<ref name=m420>Mellor p420</ref>
Thallic nickel octochloride <chem>2TlCl3.NiCl2.8H2O</chem> is bright green.<ref name=m420/>
Double bromides include the [[tetrabromonickelates]], and also caesium nickel tribromide, CsNiBr<sub>3</sub> copper nickel trioxybromide, 3Cu0·NiBr<sub>2</sub>·4H<sub>2</sub>O mercuric nickel bromide, Hg<sub>2</sub>NiBr6, HgNiBr<sub>4</sub>. Aqueous nickel bromide reacting with mercuric oxide yields mercuric nickel oxybromide, <chem>6NiO.NiBr2.HgBr2.20H2O</chem> didymium nickel bromide, <chem>2(Pr,Nd)Br3.3NiBr2.18H2O</chem> is reddish brown (mixture of praseodymium and neodymium) Lanthanum nickel bromide, <chem>2LaBr3.3NiBr2.18H2O</chem> nickel stannic bromide (or nickel bromostannate) NiSnBr<sub>6</sub>·8H<sub>2</sub>O is apple green.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Inorganic chemistry Abstracts |journal=Journal of the Chemical Society, Abstracts |date=1884 |volume=46 |pages=1254 |doi=10.1039/CA8844601254}}</ref><ref>Mellor 457</ref>
The [[tetraiodonickelates]] are blood red coloured salts of the NiI<sub>4</sub> ion with large cations. Double iodides known include mercuric nickel hexaiodide 2HgI<sub>2</sub>•NiI<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O, mercuric nickel tetraiodide HgI<sub>2</sub>•NiI<sub>2</sub>•6H<sub>2</sub>O, and lead nickel hexaiodide I<sub>2</sub>•2NiI<sub>2</sub>•3H<sub>2</sub>O.<ref name=mellor/>
The [[diperiodatonickelates]] of nickel IV are strong oxidisers, and akali monoperiodatonickelates also are known.
Nickel forms double nitrates with the lighter rare earth elements. The solid crystals have the formula <chem>Ni3Me2(NO3)12.24H2O</chem>. The metals include La Ce Pr Nd Sm Gd and the non rare earth Bi. Nickel can also be replaced by similar divalent ions, Mg, Mn Co Zn. For the nickel salts melting temperatures range from 110.5° for La, 108.5° for Ce, 108° for Pr, 105.6° for Nd, 92.2° for Sm and down to 72.5° for Gd The Bi salt melting at 69°. Crystal structure is hexagonal with Z=3.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jantsch |first1=G. |title=Zur Kenntnis der Doppelnitrate der seltenen Erden. II. Mitteilung |journal=Zeitschrift für anorganische Chemie |date=11 June 1912 |volume=76 |issue=1 |pages=303–323 |doi=10.1002/zaac.19120760112}}</ref> <chem>Ni3La2(NO3)12.24H2O</chem> becomes ferromagnetic below 0.393 K.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mess |first1=K.W. |last2=Lagendijk |first2=E. |last3=Zimmerman |first3=N.J. |last4=Van Duyneveldt |first4=A.J. |last5=Giesen |first5=J.J. |last6=Huiskamp |first6=W.J. |title=Magnetic and caloric study of the phase transitions of copper, nickel, manganese and cobalt lanthanum double nitrate |journal=Physica |date=July 1969 |volume=43 |issue=2 |pages=165–208 |doi=10.1016/0031-8914(69)90001-9|bibcode=1969Phy....43..165M }}</ref> These double nickel nitrates have been used to separate the rare earth elements by [[fractional crystallization (chemistry)|fractional crystallization]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Urbain |first1=G. |title=Sur une terre yttrique voisine du gadolinium |journal=Comptes rendus hebdomadaires des séances de l'Académie des sciences |date=1 July 1904 |volume=139 |issue=7 |pages=736–738 |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k30930/f736.image.r=|accessdate=14 July 2016}}</ref>
Nickel thorium nitrate has formula NiTh(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>6</sub>•8H<sub>2</sub>O. Nickel atoms can be substituted by other ions with radius 0.69 to 0.83 Å. The nitrates are coordinated on the thorium atom and the water to the nickel. Enthalp of solution of the octahydrate is 7 kJ/mol. Enthalpy of formation is -4360 kJ/mol. At 109° the octahydrate becomes <chem>NiTh(NO3)6.6H2O</chem>, and at 190° <chem>NiTh(NO3)6.3H2O</chem> and anhydrous at 215°.<ref name="Cherno">{{cite journal |last1=Chernorukov |first1=N. G. |last2=Knyazev |first2=A. V. |last3=Sazonov |first3=A. A. |title=Synthesis, structure, and physicochemical properties of bivalent element hexanitratothorates |journal=Radiochemistry |date=11 October 2009 |volume=51 |issue=5 |pages=437–440 |doi=10.1134/S1066362209050014}}</ref> The hexahydrate has ''Pa''{{overline|3}} cubic structure.<ref name="Cherno"/>
Various double amides containing nickel clusters have been made using liquid ammonia as a solvent. Substances made include red Li<sub>3</sub>Ni<sub>4</sub>(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>11</sub>·NH<sub>3</sub> (Pna21; Z = 4; a = 16.344(3) Å; b = 12.310(2) Å; c = 8.113(2) Å v=1631 D=1.942), and Cs<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>•NH<sub>3</sub> (P21/c; Z = 4; a =9.553(3) Å; b = 8.734(3) Å; c = 14.243(3) Å; β = 129.96(3)° V=910 D=2.960). These are called amidonickel compounds.<ref name=tenten>{{cite journal |last1=Tenten |first1=A. |last2=Jacobs |first2=H. |title=Substitutionsvarianten von Nickel(II) amid: ternäre amidoniccolate mit Lithium und Caesium Li3Ni4(NH2)11·NH3 und Cs2Ni(NH2)4·NH3 |journal=Journal of Alloys and Compounds |date=December 1991 |volume=177 |issue=2 |pages=193–217 |doi=10.1016/0925-8388(91)90074-6}}</ref> Yet others include Li<sub>4</sub>Ni<sub>4</sub>(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>12</sub>·NH<sub>3</sub>, Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jacobs |first1=Herbert |last2=Niewa |first2=Rainer |last3=Sichla |first3=Thomas |last4=Tenten |first4=Andreas |last5=Zachwieja |first5=Uwe |title=Metal nitrogen compounds with unusual chemical bonding: nitrides, imides, amides and ammine complexes |journal=Journal of Alloys and Compounds |date=January 1997 |volume=246 |issue=1–2 |pages=91–100 |doi=10.1016/S0925-8388(96)02458-9}}</ref> orange red Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>•2NH<sub>3</sub>,<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tenten |first1=A. |last2=Jacobs |first2=H. |title=Partielle Substitution von Nickel durch Natrium in Nickel(II)-amid: Isolierte Na4Ni2(NH2)8•4NH3-Einheiten in Natriumtetraamidoniccolat(II)-diammoniakat |journal=Zeitschrift für anorganische und allgemeine Chemie |date=October 1991 |volume=604 |issue=1 |pages=113–126 |language=de |doi=10.1002/zaac.19916040115}}</ref> Na<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>•NH<sub>3</sub>, K<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>•0.23KNH<sub>2</sub>, and Rb<sub>2</sub>Ni(NH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>4</sub>•0.23RbNH<sub>2</sub>.<ref name=tenten/>
Nickel dihydrogen phosphide (Ni(PH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>) can form orange, green or black double salts KNi(PH<sub>2</sub>)<sub>3</sub>) that crystallise from liquid ammonia. They are unstable above -78 °C, giving off ammonia, phosphine and hydrogen.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Schmitz-DuMont |first1=O. |last2=Uecker |first2=G. |last3=Schaal |first3=W. |title=Dihydrogenphosphide und Dihydrogenphosphidosalze der Übergangsmetalle.
